bibl.title: Letter from A. Connal to Wickliffe Rose, June 7, 1923

div1.p: Connal discusses the pathological reports of a possible yellow fever case in Lagos.

div1.head: Letter from A. Connal to Wickliffe Rose, June 7, 1923
div1.opener:
- COPY -
I. H B
A.
Africa
(W No D. & No such
MEDICAL RESEARCH INSTITUTE
Yaba,
(Near Lagos, West Africa)
7th June, 1923
Dear Dr. Wickliffe Rose:
div1.p:
I have at last obtained the post-mortem microscopic findings
in the case of the Italian, Bradenelli, who died at Warri, 9-11-22,
of suspected yellow fever. The following notes were made by Dr. Young:

"Liver shows granular degeneration of cells. Nuclei stain well.
Some lymphocytic and polymorphonuclear infiltration. No marked
fatty degeneration nor zonal destruction. In fact it fits the
description given by Professor Hoffmann in his article on Lep-
tospira experimental infection of guinea pigs - see Journal of
Tropical Medicine and Hygiene (London) page 353, of November
15th, 1922.

“Pancreas appears to me as described on page 355; kidney as on
page 354. In fact the histological results would apply rather
more to Weil's disease than yellow fever. No spirochactes
found in the silver stained preparations.”

I shall be very interested indeed to have Dr. Noguchi's
opinion.
div1.closer: Yours sincerely, (Signed) A. CONNAL Transmitted July 10/23 (Russell)
